support v Column- and bar charts
A bar chart presents categorical data with rectangular bars with heights or lengths
proportional to the values that they represent. The bars can be plotted vertically or
horizontally. Below are some common examples.
Column charts
Column charts, also known as vertical bar charts, use rectangular bars to represent
categories, with the height of each bar proportional to the values being plotted. A
simple column chart displays a single data series for straightforward comparisons.
Stacked column charts break down each bar into segments, allowing for comparisons
of parts within a whole. Clustered column charts group multiple bars together to
compare different categories side by side, using colour to distinguish between them.
Simple Stacked Clustered
Bar charts
Bar charts display data using horizontal bars. The length of each bar represents a value.
A simple bar chart is used for comparing a single variable across categories, with bars
of equal width but varying lengths. Clustered bar charts (also known as grouped bar
charts) extend this by grouping multiple bars together, allowing for comparisons across
two categorical variables, with colour distinguishing the secondary category.
Simple Clustered

Line- and area graphs
A line graph is commonly used to display change over time as a series of data points
connected by straight line segments on two axes. It can be used to show trends,
illustrate volatility and sudden peaks and valleys. Below are some common examples.
Line graphs
Line graphs show trends over time by connecting data points with a line. A simple line
graph displays one data set, while a multiple line graph compares two or more data
sets in the same graph. This makes it easy to see patterns and relationships between
them.
Simple line Multiple lines
Area graphs
Area graphs are like line graphs but with the space below the line filled with colour,
making it easier to visualise volume or totals. A simple area graph shows a single data
set, while a stacked area graph breaks it into parts, helping to see how different
categories contribute to the total over time.

Pie- and donut charts
A pie chart can be used when you want to convey the relationship or proportion of parts
to a whole, and there are few parts you need to highlight. Keep in mind, that it can be
difficult to distinguish the different parts of the pie if the sections are similar or there
are oo many slices. Below are some common examples.
Pie and donut charts are best for comparing a few data points, and especially when the
differences between the data points are significant. A pie chart is a full circle divided
into segments, while a donut chart has a gap in the middle, offering slightly different
visual characteristics while conveying the same information.
Pie Donut
Proportional area charts
Proportional area charts can be used when comparing size and quantity data. Since it’s
difficult to compare object sizes accurately, it is recommended to use proportional area
charts for communication purposes rather than analytical. Proportional area charts
usually use squares or circles. However, any shape can be used, so long as you use the
shape's area to represent the data. Below are some common examples.
Circles and squares are commonly used to compare proportions. Nested area charts
arrange these shapes within each other for a more space-efficient layout, making them
useful for visualising growth or reduction.

A gauge chart is often used to display a single metric or data field in a quantitative
context. With a shape that resembles a dial/speedometer, it allows you to easily identify
the minimum, current and the maximum value. It could, for example, be used to display
health or performance KPIs. Like the examples below.
Gauge charts help visualise progress toward a goal. A radial gauge looks like a
speedometer, with a needle pointing to the current value. A donut gauge works like a
donut chart, filling up to show progress as a percentage. A bullet gauge is a more
compact option, comparing a value to a target with additional ranges or thresholds for
context.
